questions.question: A 3-day-old child is suspected to have an inborn error of metabolism. Further evaluationreveals elevated blood ammonia in the presence of normal blood pH and bicarbonate levels.There are no ketone bodies in the urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A young infant started seizing in his cradle. He was immediately rushed to the casualty. Oninvestigation, blood ammonia was markedly elevated. Which of the following is used to lowerthe ammonia levels?Sodium benzoateb) Sodium phenylacetatec) Arginine hydrochlorided) All of the aboveQuestion 3:An infant's mother is distressed that her baby refuses her feeds and starts vomitingimmediately when fed and becomes lethargic. After thorough investigations, the baby isdiagnosed with HHH syndrome. Which of the following is least likely to be found?
questions.explanation: All of the above agents are used in the treatment of acute hyperammonemia in an infant.Treatment of acute hyperammonemia in an infant:••• Provide adequate calories, fluid, and electrolytes intravenously.• Minimal amounts of protein as a mixture of essential amino acids during the first 24 hours oftherapy.•Give priming doses of the following compounds: Sodium benzoate, Sodiumphenylacetate, Arginine hydrochloride.• Initiate peritoneal dialysis or hemodialysis if the above treatment fails to produce an appreciabledecrease in plasma ammonia levels.Benzoate forms hippurate with endogenous glycine in the liver. Each mole of benzoate removes 1mole of ammonia as glycine.Phenylacetate conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine, which is readily excretedin the urine. One mole of phenylacetate removes 2 moles of ammonia as glutamine from the body.Arginine administration supplies the urea cycle with ornithine. It is effective in all patients, exceptthose with arginase deficiency.Note:Phenylbutyrate which is metabolized to phenylacetate in our body can also be used as it scavengesnitrogen.

questions.question: As a geneticist studying the familial inheritance of porphyrias, which of the following is likelyto show the inheritance pattern given below?OMARROW
questions.explanation: The given pedigree chart shows X-linked dominant inheritance. X-linked protoporphyria isinherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.All porphyrias are autosomal dominant except the following:•Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP) (autosomal recessive)• 8-Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase porphyria (ADP) (autosomal recessive)• Protoporphyria - X-linked protoporphyria (X-linked dominant).Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP) (autosomal recessive)

questions.question: The most common porphyria which manifests in childhood is
questions.explanation: Erythropoietic protoporphyria (autosomal recessive) is the most common porphyria to manifest inchildhood.Porphyria cutanea tarda (option A) manifests in adults.Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (option B) also known as Günther disease presents itself inutero or in infancy. It is a rare autosomal-recessive disease.Hereditary coproporphyria (option D) presents itself in the post-pubertal age.

questions.question: Which of the following is also known as plumboporphyria due to its clinical similarity to leadpoisoning?
questions.explanation: 8-Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase porphyria (ALAD) is also called plumboporphyria/Dossporphyria due to its clinical similarity to lead poisoning, although it is not related to leadexposure.ALAD catalyzes the condensation of 2 molecules of ALA to form the pyrrole porphobilinogen(PBG). The enzyme is subject to inhibition by lead because ALAD is the principal lead-bindingprotein in erythrocytes, and lead can displace the zinc atoms of the enzyme, thus inhibiting it.Therefore, both lead poisoning and ALAD porphyria produce similar signs andsymptoms. Symptoms resemble those of other acute porphyrias, including acute attacks ofabdominal pain and neuropathy.

questions.question: A 16-year-old girl was admitted for severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.She developed generalized seizures in the hospital for which she was given phenytoin. Hersymptoms worsened, she developed muscle weakness which progressed to quadriparesis.Urinary porphobilinogen was found to be high. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The most likely diagnosis is acute intermittent porphyria which presents as a neurovisceralsyndrome with no cutaneous manifestations and no phototoxicity.Acute Intermittent Porphyria:• Autosomal dominant• Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase271• Presents at post-pubertal age• Present with hepatic and neurologic manifestations•Exacerbated by P450 inducing drugs like phenytoin, progesterone and dietary restriction

questions.question: You are reading an article titled, ' Dark age vampires or our patients', which describes an18-year-old man who has had an intolerance to sunshine since the age of 6. When playingcricket he suffered intense burning, redness, swelling, and crusting of knees unprotected byshorts, with similar changes on cheeks and bridge of the nose. His labs showed elevatedconcentrations of total erythrocyte protoporphyrin. Which of the following enzymedeficiencies can explain this boy's condition?
questions.explanation: Symptoms of cutaneous photosensitivity beginning in childhood and a substantially elevatedconcentration of total erythrocyte protoporphyrin supports a diagnosis of erythropoieticprotoporphyria. The enzyme deficient in erythropoietic protoporphyria is ferrochelatase (FECH).Symptoms consist of acute pain and itching often occurring within minutes of sunlight exposureand followed by redness and swelling with continued exposure. Swelling may resembleangioneurotic edema and solar urticaria. Symptoms are usually worse in the spring and summer.Chronic changes may include lichenification, leathery pseudovesicles, labial grooving, and nailchanges, but changes in pigmentation and pronounced scarring are unusual.Life-threatening protoporphyric hepatopathy is characterized by greater increases in erythrocyteand plasma protoporphyrin levels, increased photosensitivity, and either chronically abnormalliver function tests or rapidly progressive hepatic failure.

questions.question: A 6-month-old baby boy has coarse facial features, cloudy corneas, and gingival hypertrophy.He has no neck control and is unable to roll over. Laboratory investigations reveal markedlyreduced activity of N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase activity in WBCs. What is themost likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of I-cell disease or inclusion cell disease. It is alsoknown as type II Mucolipidosis.It is an autosomal recessive inherited as a lysosomal storage disorder. It is caused due to a defectin N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase required for the Golgi to phosphorylate mannoseresidues on glycoproteins. This leads to defective mannose-6-phosphate, an important cellsignaling molecule required for trafficking of the lysosomal enzyme from the site of its productionin the endoplasmic reticulum to the lysosome. Due to this defect, the lysosomal enzymes aresecreted out of the cell and there is an increased serum concentration of the same. Intracellularly,there are abnormal inclusion bodies and vacuolizations, thus earning the disease its name.Clinically, these patients present with symptoms either at birth or early in life with growthretardation, failure to thrive, delay of developmental milestones, coarse facial features with acloudy cornea and gingival hypertrophy, and other non-specific findings such as hip dislocations,inguinal hernias, hepatomegaly, joint limitation, and skin changes.Investigations to establish a diagnosis may includemeasuring N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase activity in WBCs or in cultured fibroblastsand estimating serum levels of lysosomal enzymes.Option B: Galactosemia is caused due to the complete absence of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to an inability to convert galactose-1-phosphate(galactose-1-P) to uridine diphosphate galactose. It is characterized by typical clinical featuressuch as jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, poor feeding, lethargy, diarrhea,E.Coli sepsis. Infants may also have edema, ascites, full fontanelle, encephalopathy, and excessive272bruising and bleeding. They tend to develop cataracts due to the accumulation of galactitol.Option C: Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder of ẞ-oxidation of fatty acids.There is a very large chain fatty acids buildup in the adrenal glands, the white matter of the brain,and testes. It is a progressive disease that can lead to adrenal gland crisis, coma, and death.Option D: Hurler syndrome is an important diagnosis in a patient presenting with clinical featuresgiven in this clinical vignette. But it is a mucopolysaccharidosis type 1-H caused due by the defectin the α-L Iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparin sulfate and dermatan sulfate. It ischaracterized by skeletal abnormalities, hepatosplenomegaly, and severe intellectual disability.Infants develop characteristic coarse facial features, a wide nasal bridge, and a flattened midface.Features such as hepatosplenomegaly, umbilical or inguinal hernias, and typical skeletalabnormalities, known as dysostosis multiplex laos are also seen. They also have developmentaldelays and recurrent sinopulmonary diseases. Failure to thrive and growth restriction are alsoseen.

questions.question: An 8-year-old boy is brought with complaints of severe pain in his right thigh which hasprogressively worsened over the last few months. He is unable to walk because of the same.His mother also says he has had repeated nose bleeds in the last few months and the childhas stopped playing with his friends as he gets easily tired for a month. Physical examinationreveals hepatosplenomegaly. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and anemia. An assay ofperipheral blood leucocytes shows low levels of beta-glucosidase. What is the inheritancepattern of this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of bone pain, epistaxis, hepatosplenomegaly, and low levelsof ẞ-glucosidase suggests a diagnosis of Gaucher's disease that is inherited in an autosomalrecessive pattern.Gaucher's disease:••It is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase(ẞ-glucosidase) that leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in the lysosomes of cells.It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder.• The clinical features result from the accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the spleen,liver, bone marrow, bone, and other tissues.• There are 3 clinical subtypes, delineated by the absence or presence and progression ofneurologic manifestations: type 1, or the adult, nonneuronopathic form; type 2, the infantile oracute neuronopathic form; and type 3, the juvenile or subacute neuronopathic form• Typical clinical features include delayed puberty, painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly, livercirrhosis, hypersplenism and pancytopenia, bleeding tendencies, bone pain due to avascularnecrosis, osteoporosis, pathological fractures.• Neurological symptoms such as developmental delay, hypertonia, strabismus, supranuclear gazepalsy (seen in type 3).•• Bone marrow examination usually reveals the presence of Gaucher cells (have acharacteristic wrinkled-paper appearance)• Enzyme replacement therapy for Gaucher's disease: imiglucerase, velaglucerasealfa, taliglucerase alfa,eliglustat

questions.question: A 6-month-old infant with progressive failure to thrive and milestone regression is beingevaluated for an inborn error of metabolism. On examination, hypotonia, apathy, deafness,hepatosplenomegaly, and generalized lymphadenopathy are present. Fundus examination isshown below. A liver biopsy shows foamy hepatocytes loaded with sphingomyelin. Electronmicroscopy reveals zebra bodies. What is the likely diagnosis?263
questions.explanation: 273The clinical vignette along with the cherry-red spot on fundus examination suggests a diagnosis ofNiemann-Pick disease type A- Lysosomal storage disorder due to an inherited deficiency ofsphingomyelinaseType A is a severe infantile form with extensive neurologic involvement (hypotonia, milestoneregression, apathy), marked visceral accumulations of sphingomyelin (hepatosplenomegaly, foamyhepatocytes, zebra bodies on EM), and progressive wasting and early death within the first 3 yearsof life.In contrast, patients with Niemann-Pick disease type B have organomegaly but generally no CNSinvolvement.

questions.question: A male child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips with hepatosplenomegaly presentswith copious mucous discharge from the nose. The most probable underlying diagnosis is
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of a child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips,hepatosplenomegaly, and copious discharge from the nose is suggestive of Hurler's disease.It is the severe form of mucopolysaccharidoses type 1 (MPS 1), an autosomal recessive disordercaused by a defect in α-L iduronidase, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulfate anddermatan sulfate. The child usually presents between 6 and 24 months with hepatosplenomegaly,coarse facial features (shown below), corneal clouding, large tongue, prominent forehead, jointstiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.Most patients have recurrent upper respiratory tract and ear infections, noisy breathing, andpersistent copious nasal discharge. Radiograph shows skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosismultiplex - thick ribs, ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged and trabeculated diaphyses of the longbones with irregular metaphysis and epiphysis.Macrocephaly, enlarged J-shaped sella, premature closure of lambdoid sagittal sutures, andshallow orbits are seen with disease progression. Obstructive airway disease, cardiaccomplications, and respiratory infections are the common causes of death.The image below shows the radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpal andphalanges.274Other options:Option B: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth syndrome characterized bymacrosomia, macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, omphalocele, and renal anomalies. It is associatedwith an increased risk of Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, neuroblastoma, andadrenal cortical carcinoma.Option C: Proteus syndrome is a disturbance of cellular growth involving ectodermal andmesodermal tissues, caused by mutation in the AKT1 gene. They present withhemimegalencephaly, asymmetric overgrowth of the extremities, verrucous cutaneous lesions,thickening of the bone, and excessive growth of muscles.Option D: A child with untreated congenital hypothyroidism may have stunted growth, shortextremities, narrow palpebral fissures, swollen eyelids, depressed nasal bridge, thick broadprotruded tongue, and short and thick neck, dry and scaly skin.

questions.question: A case series reviews children with lysosomal storage disorders who usually present withdysmorphic facies, organomegaly, milestones regression, and failure to thrive. Which of thefollowing disorders does not have enzyme replacement therapy as a therapeutic option?
questions.explanation: Enzyme replacement therapy is not available for Sanfilippo syndrome (MPS type III).

questions.question: A 3-month-old female child was brought to the clinic with a history of failure to thrive. Onexamination, generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. A chest X-ray imageshows massive cardiomegaly. A muscle biopsy is performed and the findings are attached inthe image below. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme that is involved in thesuspected condition?
questions.explanation: The muscle biopsy shows the presence of large vacuoles. This along with the clinical vignette isstrongly suggestive of Pompe's disease or type II glycogen storage disease. It is caused due to thedeficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase.Clinically, the child presents with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Theaffected child usually dies around the age of 2 years due to heart failure.Investigations include chest X-ray imaging which shows cardiomegaly. The muscle biopsyshowing vacuoles further aids the diagnosis.Treatment includes enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant enzyme a-glucosidase alfa(Myozyme).

questions.question: A 6-month-old is brought by his parents with a history of decreased weight gain. Onexamination, you find that the baby has hepatosplenomegaly, muscle weakness and atrophy,hypotonia, and decreased deep tendon reflexes. Blood tests reveal normal glucose levels.Biopsy of the liver reveals initial stages of cirrhosis due to the accumulation of abnormalglycogen with few branch points, whose structure resembles amylopectin. The clinical andlaboratory results are indicative of which glycogen storage disease?
questions.explanation: The clinical and laboratory features indicate Andersen's disease in the baby. Inability to gainweight, hepatosplenomegaly, muscle weakness, and accumulation of abnormal glycogenresembling amylopectin point towards the diagnosis.Andersen's disease is type IV glycogen storage disease. It is transmitted in an autosomal recessivepattern and occurs due to a deficiency of glycogen branching enzyme because of pathologicvariants in the GBE1 gene. This leads to accumulation of of an abnormal structure of glycogenknown as polyglucosan. It is characterized by275• Growth delay•••Hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of polysaccharides with few branch pointsMyopathyThere might be fasting intolerance and ketosis in the initial stages. Hypoglycemia usuallyappears late in the disease when it is associated with cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and ascites..• Biopsy of the liver will show the presence of abnormal glycogen which resembles amylopectin.Amylopectin is found in plants and has very few branches. Since there is a defect in the branchingof the glycogen, the abnormal glycogen appears like amylopectin.The diagnosis is confirmed by absent branching enzyme activity in skin fibroblasts, muscle, orliver and analysis of the DNA mutation.Von Gierke's disease (Option A) has features of lactic acidosis, hypoglycemia, hyperuricemia,impaired growth, and bone thinning. It occurs due to a defect in the glucose 6-phosphatase.McArdle disease (Option C) usually manifests as exercise intolerance, muscle cramping withexercise. It is usually a benign chronic condition. It occurs due to a defect in the muscle glycogenphosphorylase.Tarui disease (Option D) also presents similar to the McArdle disease. Patients may havedevelopmental delay, and hemolytic anemia in addition to exercise-induced muscle cramps. Itoccurs due to a defect in the muscle phosphofructokinase.

questions.question: A 6-year-old boy develops hypoglycemia and muscle weakness with moderate activity. Onexamination, he had hepatomegaly and growth restriction. Investigations revealed theaccumulation of limit dextrins and increased glycogen deposits in the liver. What is the mostlikely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The most likely diagnosis is Cori disease.Glycogen debrancher deficiency (Glycogen Storage Disease III) is also known as Cori disease,Forbes disease, and limit dextrinosis.Cori's disease may be clinically indistinguishable from von Gierke's disease in infancy andchildhood as hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and growth retardation is common.Accumulation of limit dextrins is unique to Cori's disease. Definitive diagnosis is through enzymeassays in the liver, muscle, or both.

questions.question: A 5-day-old neonate is brought to the emergency room with vomiting and poor feeding.Breastfeeding was initiated soon after birth. On examination, the child is lethargic and hashepatomegaly. Labs reveal increased plasma galactose and increased urine galactitol levels.Examination of the mother shows the presence of skin lesions on the breast with thehistopathological appearance showing characteristic 'Cowdry Type A' inclusions as shownbelow. Choose the correct statements from those below:
questions.explanation: The given clinical complex describes a case of classic galactosemia in the infant (increased plasmagalactose and urine galactitol levels) and herpes simplex of the breast in the mother(histopathology shown in the image has large multinucleate virus-infected cells withtypical eosinophilic Cowdry Type A inclusions).Galactosemia is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding and the child is at risk for E.colisepsis. Herpes lesions on the breast are a relative contraindication to breastfeeding and she is atrisk for recurrence.276Deficiency of galactose-1-uridyltransferase leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphateand galactitol causes classic galactosemia.Infants show vomiting, diarrhea, and poor weight gain within 3-4 days of breastfeeding.Jaundiceand liver dysfunction appear in the first or second week of life. Untreated children may shownuclear cataracts (oil-droplet cataract), vitreous hemorrhage, hepatic failure, cirrhosis, ascites,splenomegaly, or intellectual disability. The proximal renal tubular disease may also manifest asmetabolic acidosis, galactosuria, glucosuria, and aminoaciduria. The most common cause of deathis E.coli sepsis.Acute galactose toxicity is manifested by neurological symptomsDiagnosis is made by genetic or mutational analysis. There will the presence of reducingsubstances in the urine. Elimination of galactose from the diet along with adequate calciumsupplementation reverses growth failure and renal and hepatic dysfunction.

questions.question: A father has noticed that whenever his daughter drinks fruit juice she has multiple episodesof vomiting. He reports to you that his daughter is allergic to fruit juice. Which of thefollowing enzyme deficiency is likely?
questions.explanation: Aldolase B deficiency is likely in this child.In the given case scenario, the child becomes symptomatic after ingesting fruit juice that containsfructose; this indicates that she has hereditary fructose intolerance, which is caused by thedeficiency of aldolase B.Deficiency of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate aldolase (Aldolase B hereditary fructoseintolerance): Fructose aldolase B is present in the liver, kidney, and intestine. It catalyzes thehydrolysis of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate into triose phosphate and glyceraldehyde phosphate.Clinical features: Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually fromfruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). Clinical features include jaundice,hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. It resembles galactosemia. Acuteingestion causes symptomatic hypoglycemia. Chronic intake results in failure to thrive and hepaticdisease. The persistence of fructose intake can lead to liver failure, kidney failure, and death.Diagnosis: Reducing substance is seen in the urine during an episode (Benedict's test +). Anassay of fructaldolase B activity in the liver gives a definitive diagnosis.Treatment: Complete elimination of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet.With age, symptoms become milder even after fructose ingestion. The long-term prognosis isgood.Note:The deficiency of fructokinase is not associated with any clinical manifestations. Fructosuria is anaccidental finding usually made because the asymptomatic patient's urine contains a reducingsubstance. No treatment is necessary, and the prognosis is excellent.

questions.question: "Tomcat urine" is characteristically seen in
questions.explanation: Tomcat urine is characteristically seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency.It is named so because of its peculiar odour.277

questions.question: The enzyme deficient in hereditary coproporphyria is
questions.explanation: The enzyme deficient in hereditary coproporphyria is coproporphyrinogen oxidase (CPOX).Hereditary coproporphyria (HCP):• Autosomal-dominant hepatic porphyria is caused by the deficiency of CPOX.•• Acute attacks of HCP are treated as in acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), which includesintravenous hemin and identifying and avoiding precipitating factors. Cholestyramine may be ofsome value for photosensitivity occurring with liver dysfunction.•⚫ Gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogs can be effective for the prevention of cyclic attacks.

questions.question: Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase causes267
questions.explanation: Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase causes acute intermittent porphyria.Other options:•Porphyria cutanea tarda: Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD)• Variegate porphyria: Deficiency of Protoporphyrinogen oxidase (PPOX)• X-Linked protoporphyria: Gain of function mutation of 8-aminolevulinate synthase 2 (ALAS2)

questions.question: A mother who is a hairstylist has noted that her baby's hair looks dull, breaks off easily, and istufted. She brings the child to you and informs you about the past history of seizures.Investigations reveal elevated plasma ammonia levels and argininosuccinate levels. What isthe most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The most likely diagnosis is argininosuccinic aciduria due to argininosuccinate lyase deficiency.It is accompanied by high levels of argininosuccinate levels in blood, CSF, and urine. It is alsoassociated with friable, tufted hair known as trichorrhexis nodosa.Image showing Trichorrhexis nodosa:278

questions.question: Accumulation oftakes place in Farber's disease.
questions.explanation: Accumulation of Ceramide is seen in Farber's disease due to ceramidase deficiency.Clinical features of Farber's disease:• Painful joint swelling, nodules, progressive joint deformity• Hoarse cry• Breathing difficulty• Failure to thrive279
